BK1.competency: Understands the business process and technology used by business partners, including the impact to the client experience.

examples.0: Does not have a clear understanding of the immediate business processes, technology, or client impact.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of the business and technology processes to handle requests, but may need assistance.
examples.2: Has a detailed knowledge of the business and technology processes, and the general impact to its clients.
examples.3: Has a detailed knowledge of the business and technology processes and ties threads with dependencies to ensure a positive impact to the client experience.

BK2.competency: Proactively shares business and technology knowledge with other team members.

examples.0: Does not share information with the team.
examples.1: Shares information with the team when prompted or requested.
examples.2: Proactively shares knowledge with the team.
examples.3: Proactively shares knowledge beyond the team to ensure integration coverage and provides the necessary business and technology documentation for clarity and visibility.

BK3.competency: Identifies technology gaps that could support the long-term needs of the business.

examples.0: Does not identify technology gaps.
examples.1: Identifies technology gaps in basic processes.
examples.2: Consistently identifies technology gaps in complex processes
examples.3: Consistently identifies technology gaps in any process, and proactively takes ownership in creating a solution.

BK4.competency: Accounts for and raises awareness of critical work or project characteristics: size of the project, business risks, system interfaces, training requirements and business processes to follow or revise.

examples.0: Does not tie the threads around work items.
examples.1: Ties the threads around work items within the team, with assistance.
examples.2: Consistently ties the threads around work items, within the team.
examples.3: Consistently ties the threads around work items, including integrations to applicable applications or services or systems.

BK5.competency: Makes decisions on the best technology solutions, while working with business and technology partners.

examples.0: Does not, or frequently need guidance, to make a decision on the best technology solution.
examples.1: Makes decisions on the best technology solution, for the team's basic domain processes.
examples.2: Consistently makes decisions on the best technology solutions for the team's basic and complex domain processes, and involves the appropriate business and technology partners.
examples.3: Valued as the go-to person to make decisions on the best technology solution for complex processes involving the team's and dependent team's domain processes while leveraging business and technology partners.

BK6.competency: Actively monitors change notifications (i.e. change notices, push plans, release notes, etc.) to help identify changes that could have a negative impact in Production.

examples.0: Monitors change notifications only occasionally.
examples.1: Monitors change notifications for the team's domain.
examples.2: Consistently monitors change notifications for the team's domain and takes action when needed.
examples.3: Consistently monitors change notifications in and out of the team's domain and takes action when needed.

BK7.competency: Works with IT or business partners to resolve critical production issues that arise.

examples.0: Does not participate in the resolution of production issues.
examples.1: Helps with the resolution of production issues when asked.
examples.2: consistently in tune with production issue communications affecting the immediate team's domain, raises awareness to the team, and provides assistance.
examples.3: Consistently in tune with production issue communications affecting the immediate team's and dependent team's domains, raises awareness to the team(s) and provides assistance.

BK8.competency: Seeks opportunities to grow and gain knowledge about the business.

examples.0: Does not actively seek opportunities to grow their business knowledge.
examples.1: Acts in a reactive manner to grow business knowledge in the area they support.
examples.2: Proactively seeks opportunities to grow business knowledge in the area they support.
examples.3: Proactively seeks opportunities to grow business knowledge in and out of their area.

TV1.competency: Is able to get buy-in of development teams and business partners for their technical vision, specific to solutions for requests (tasks, stories, etc.).

examples.0: Does not contribute to, or focus on, a technical vision for requests.
examples.1: Provides a focus of skills toward the technical vision of a request, with guidance.
examples.2: Consistently and independently finds and executes on opportunities to promote a technical vision of a request, within their team.
examples.3: Consistently and independently promotes and ties the technical vision of a request to technology partners when necessary, and overall Technology Philosophies.

TV2.competency: Looks for opportunities for an application's overall improvement, setting goals for the application to strive for.

examples.0: Does not have enough familiarity with the application to understand the opportunities.
examples.1: Aware of application opportunities and communicates them to others.
examples.2: Aware of application opportunities and consistently works to get them implemented.
examples.3: Proactively finds opportunities and executes on improvements related to the application and engages other teams.

TV3.competency: Adheres to the technical vision of the team's system or application.

examples.0: Does not contributed to or focus on a vision for the team's domain.
examples.1: Provides a concentration toward the technical vision of the team's domain, but may need guidance.
examples.2: Consistently and independently finds and executes on opportunities to promote and ensure alignment with the team's domain.
examples.3: Consistently and independently finds and executes on opportunities to promote and ensure alignment with the team's systems or application with the technology partners.

TV4.competency: Participates in enterprise-level technology discussions, helping drive the enterprise technology direction.

examples.0: Does not participate in enterprise-level discussions.
examples.1: Occasionally involved with enterprise-level discussions.
examples.2: Consistently involved with enterprise-level discussions.
examples.3: Consistently seeks and acts on opportunities to participate in enterprise-level discussions and is brought in as the go-to person consistently.

TV5.competency: Ensures solutions adhere to the enterprise-level security standards.

examples.0: Does not consistently consider or identify security risks as part of their solution.
examples.1: Aware of the security standards and considers them, but may need assistance addressing them as a part of a solution.
examples.2: Consistently considers security protocol and ensures they are covered in basic solutions.
examples.3: Consistently and proactively considers security protocol and ensures they are covered in all solutions.

RB1.competency: Actively develops relationships with the team and throughout technology.

examples.0: Minimal to no interaction within the team.
examples.1: Builds relationships within the team.
examples.2: Builds meaningful and beneficial relationships with business and technology partners and stakeholders associated with the team.
examples.3: Proactively builds meaningful and beneficial relationships with all partners, stakeholders, and other areas of the company.

RB2.competency: Seeks out and contributes to initiatives, beyond the planned or routine daily responsibilities, with the team and throughout technology.

examples.0: Does not actively contribute to any initiatives.
examples.1: Contributes to initiatives with the team in day-to-day activities.
examples.2: Consistently contributes to and leads initiatives for the team that are outside of day-to-day activities.
examples.3: Actively seeks out, contributes, and helps lead initiatives across Technology.

examples.0: Does not mentor any team members.
examples.1: Mentors team members within the team when requested.
examples.2: Consistently volunteers to mentor team members inside the team.
examples.3: Consistently mentors team members inside the team and team members of the larger Technology area or of technology partner teams.

RB4.competency: Steps up within the team to organize and lead activities to promote team bonding and growth.

examples.0: Does not help organize these activities.
examples.1: Steps up to help organize and lead activities when asked or with assistance.
examples.2: Consistently volunteers to take the lead to organize and lead activities inside the team.
examples.3: Proactively finds opportunities to organize and lead activities for the larger Technology area.

C1.competency: Articulates in a gump manner, applying basic communication skills (tone, physiology, words) to ensure the intended message is received.

examples.0: Does not communicate effectively.
examples.1: Communicates in this manner, but needs occasional coaching or needs to occasionally ask or answer follow-up questions for clarity.
examples.2: Consistently communicates effectively in this manner to ensure the message is received.
examples.3: Consistently communicates effectively in this manner with any audience and situation.

C2.competency: Provides proactive updates and visibility to impacted stakeholders and business leaders.

examples.0: Does not communicate frequently enough.
examples.1: Provides frequent updates to stakeholders when necessary.
examples.2: Consistently provides proactive updates to stakeholders.
examples.3: Consistently provides proactive updates and shares information across technology when applicable.

C3.competency: Creates documentation (NFR documentation, change notices, write-ups, test plans, etc.) to ensure clarity on changes and processes.

examples.0: Does not create documentation related to their or their team's immediate work.
examples.1: Consistently creates adequate documentation related to their own or their team's immediate work.
examples.2: Creates standards, gives advice, and drives the execution for team documentation.
examples.3: Gives input and implements documentation standards beyond the team and for the larger area.

C4.competency: Organizes and conducts effective meetings with the following: a clear agenda, right audience, proper frequency, timeliness, and desired outcome, ensuring all team members are engaged and have a chance to contribute.

examples.0: Does not successfully organize effective meetings.
examples.1: Organizes and leads meetings with assistance.
examples.2: Independently and consistently organizes and leads successful meetings with the smaller group of normal stakeholders.
examples.3: Independently and consistently organizes and leads large meetings with many stakeholders across several areas.

C5.competency: Organizes and leads discussions to promote best practices and standards.

examples.0: Provides minimal or no participation in discussions to promote best practices and standards.
examples.1: Participates in discussions to promote best practices and standards within the team, when available.
examples.2: Consistently organizes and leads discussions to promote best practices and standards within the team.
examples.3: Consistently and effectively organizes and leads discussions to promote best practices and standards in and outside of the team, including business and technology partners.

C6.competency: Effectively presents to business users and IT team members.

examples.0: Does not or rarely presents to business users and IT team members.
examples.1: Presents to business users and IT team members when needed.
examples.2: Takes advantage of opportunities to effectively present to the team's business users and members.
examples.3: Consistently and effectively presents and engages across the organization including senior leaders.

RG1.competency: Actively listens and asks key questions to understand impact, gather requirements, and identify dependencies.

examples.0: Does not actively listen or participate in conversations to understand the necessary info to move forward and requires extensive follow up conversations to gather information.
examples.1: Participates in conversations by listening well and asking relevant questions for basic requests. Needs assistance to go deeper to gather all requirements. Requires some follow up clarifying conversations.
examples.2: Independently and consistently practices effective listening skills by asking deep questions to ensure all requirements are understood for basic and complex requests.
examples.3: Independently and consistently drives requirements sessions through highly effective listening and questioning for requirements including multiple applications and systems.

RG2.competency: Clearly defines and documents requirements and acceptance criteria for scalable and reusable solutions.

examples.0: Provides only very limited or high level basic documentation without essential details.
examples.1: Defines detailed requirements and quality acceptance criteria with documentation for basic requests that team members easily understand.
examples.2: Consistently and independently defines detailed requirements and acceptance criteria with accurate documentation for basic and complex requests and factors in scalability, reusability, and integration.
examples.3: Works effectively as part of a larger team (projects, epics, etc.) to identify and define detailed requirements and acceptance criteria with accurate documentation for multiple applications and systems.

RG3.competency: Understands the team's current state of technology and business processes to ensure new changes will not negatively impact these processes.

examples.0: Does not understand the current state of technology and business process they are changing.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of the technology and business process associated with typical changes to the requests they and the team support.
examples.2: Fully understands the technology and business process associated with the entire team and communicates within the team effectively to ensure processes remain intact.
examples.3: Fully understands the team's business and technology process and works extensively to ensure the processes remain intact for integrations and projects.

RG4.competency: Effectively works with stakeholders to identify and analyze requests and define solutions.

examples.0: Has no experience or is not successful working with stakeholders to identify root causes.
examples.1: Works with stakeholders to identify and understand simple problems and define solutions.
examples.2: Effectively works with stakeholders to identify and understand complex problems and causes, and define solutions.
examples.3: Consistently and independently works well with stakeholders to identify problems of all complexities, including all integrations, and define solutions.

RG5.competency: Actively engages SMEs to review solutions, helping to learn newer and better ways to develop solutions and ensure the highest quality.

examples.0: Does not leverage SMEs for advice or input on solutions.
examples.1: Leverages SMEs for advice and input on up-to-date options for solutions.
examples.2: Consistently and independently understands which SMEs to leverage and how to implement the input and options for solutions.
examples.3: Has a strong network and practice of collaboration with SMEs to proactively understand changes to implement into solutions.

RG6.competency: Breaks work down so it can be delivered in the most effective and efficient way possible.

examples.0: Is able to break down work for easier solutions with assistance.
examples.1: Independently breaks down work for easier solutions.
examples.2: Consistently and independently breaks down work for complex solutions.
examples.3: Excels at breaking down their own work, as well as work that spans multiple teams and systems, and provides direction as the work progresses.

examples.0: Provides unrealistic estimates for smaller and easier defined tasks or frequently requires assistance.
examples.1: Provides realistic estimates for smaller and easier defined tasks without assistance.
examples.2: Consistently provides accurate estimates for easier and complex tasks without assistance.
examples.3: Consistently provides accurate estimates and asks effective questions to lead input on large or complex changes.

RG8.competency: Leverages the best tools, processes, and team members to provide solutions.

examples.0: Is unaware of the tools, processes, or team members available to help provide solutions.
examples.1: Leverages the available tools, processes, and team members to solve basic problems, with guidance.
examples.2: Consistently and independently leverages the available tools, processes, and team members to solve problems within their role and team.
examples.3: Consistently and independently leverages the available tools, processes, and team to solve complex problems, including integrations across teams.

RG9.competency: Utilizes enterprise architecture diagrams to develop solutions.

examples.0: Does not utilize enterprise architecture diagrams.
examples.1: Utilizes enterprise architecture diagrams, but may need assistance.
examples.2: Consistently and independently leverages the architecture diagrams to develop quality solutions.
examples.3: Consistently and independently leverages the architecture diagrams to develop complex, quality solutions involving integrations.

RG10.competency: Considers services and APIs when defining solutions.

examples.0: Does not consider services and APIs when defining solutions.
examples.1: Defines solutions with services and APIs in mind, but may need assistance.
examples.2: Fully understands services and APIs and considers them when creating simple solutions.
examples.3: Fully understands services and APIs and considers them when creating complex solutions.

T1.competency: Defines test scenarios based on the requested changes.

examples.0: Does not understand the specifications and does not define test scenarios.
examples.1: Understands functional and design specifications at a basic level, and defines test scenarios.
examples.2: Consistently and independently defines basic test scenarios.
examples.3: Consistently and independently defines complex test scenarios.

T2.competency: Creates and executes detailed test plans.

examples.0: Does not create and execute test plans.
examples.1: Develops, executes, and validates test plans at a basic level.
examples.2: Consistently and independently develops, executes, and validates basic test cases.
examples.3: Consistently and independently develops, executes, and validates complex test plans for any scenario. Can execute and develop a test plan regardless of who created the test plan.

T3.competency: Executes regression tests, ensuring the existing process is not negatively impacted.

examples.0: Does not execute on regression testing.
examples.1: Understands regression testing for basic processes and executes.
examples.2: Consistently and independently executes basic regression testing scenarios.
examples.3: Consistently and independently executes complex regression testing scenarios.

T4.competency: Is able to identify testing bugs, track the issues, and work to successfully resolve them.

examples.0: Does not identify or act on testing bugs.
examples.1: Identifies and acts on testing bugs at a basic level.
examples.2: Consistently and independently identifies and acts on bugs and testing issues in basic scenarios by utilizing available testing tools and applications.
examples.3: Consistently and independently identifies and acts on bugs and testing issues for complex scenarios by utilizing available testing tools and applications.

SD1.competency: Seeks out new technology skills to enhance their knowledge.

examples.0: Does not proactively seek out new technology skills.
examples.1: Reactively seeks out new technology skills.
examples.2: Proactively seeks out new technology skills for their own system or application.
examples.3: Proactively seeks out new technology skills for their own system, other systems and integrations, and technology that could be a possibility in the future.

SD2.competency: Seeks out growth opportunities and guidance to improve soft skills such as communication, attitude, organization, etc.

examples.0: Does not seek out or implement feedback for these skills.
examples.1: Reactively seeks out growth opportunities and implements feedback when given.
examples.2: Proactively seeks out growth opportunities for their immediate responsibilities by requesting and implementing feedback.
examples.3: Proactively seeks out growth opportunities beyond their responsibilities and area by requesting and implementing feedback.

SD3.competency: Develops skills by seeking mentorship and participating in activities such as Hack Week, online learning, community participation, conferences, etc.

examples.0: Does not actively participate in any extra activities.
examples.1: Seeks mentorship and participates in extra activities to develop skills when suggested.
examples.2: Proactively seeks mentorship and participates in extra activities to develop skills for their immediate responsibilities.
examples.3: Proactively seeks mentorship and leads extra activities to develop skills for opportunities beyond their responsibilities and area.

examples.0: Tends to focus on the negative.
examples.1: Typically displays a positive attitude towards their work and team members.
examples.2: Consistently displays a positive attitude towards their work and team members.
examples.3: Consistently displays a positive attitude towards their work and team members, and spreads this attitude to others.

examples.0: Is not adaptable.
examples.1: Can be adaptable, but may take a period of time to adjust.
examples.2: Adapts well and displays a positive attitude to get others to buy in to change for the team.
examples.3: Quickly and easily adapts to change with an open mind and positive attitude, and champions the change outside of the team.

examples.0: Does not manage time effectively and does not meet commitments.
examples.1: Manages their day, but occasionally is sidetracked by noise or needs to work longer hours to meet commitments.
examples.2: Effectively prioritizes their day to consistently complete tasks as planned.
examples.3: Effectively prioritizes beyond the immediate day to consistently meet commitments, and knows when to re-prioritize and leverage help.

CP4.competency: Responds with a sense of urgency.

examples.0: Does not respond with a sense of urgency.
examples.1: Responds with a sense of urgency, but may not be able to see things through to completion as quickly.
examples.2: Consistently responds with a sense of urgency and a positive attitude. Is able to see things through to completion in an appropriate time frame.
examples.3: Consistently responds with a sense of urgency and a positive attitude. Has a calm demeanor and sees things through to completion with the same sense of urgency and attitude.

CP5.competency: Balances multiple tasks with specific due dates, priority, and levels of difficulty.

examples.0: Does not balance multiple tasks to effectively make expected progress.
examples.1: Balances tasks that are lower in complexity and makes expected progress with assistance.
examples.2: Consistently and independently balances tasks to make expected progress.
examples.3: Consistently and independently balances complex tasks and meets demanding deadlines.
